channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump continues to threaten military action against Iran
item.description: Amid a deadly crackdown on protesters in Iran, President Trump continues to threaten military action against Tehran and warned countries that do business with Iran that he could impose a tariff.
item.content:encoded: Amid a deadly crackdown on protesters in Iran, President Trump continues to threaten military action against Tehran and warned countries that do business with Iran that he could impose a tariff.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Iran expert talks about the Trump administration's strategy with Iran
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Iran expert Karim Sadjadpour about the U.S. strategy toward Iran and why he believes Iran's regime could collapse.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Iran expert Karim Sadjadpour about the U.S. strategy toward Iran and why he believes Iran's regime could collapse.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: UN International Court of Justice to hear 1st genocide case in over a decade
item.description: The United Nations International Court of Justice is hearing a genocide case for the first time in more than a decade. The case is focused on the persecution of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.
item.content:encoded: The United Nations International Court of Justice is hearing a genocide case for the first time in more than a decade. The case is focused on the persecution of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: Today is the Smithsonian's deadline to give thousands of documents to the White House
item.description: The White House says the Smithsonian Institution must submit materials about current and upcoming exhibitions and events for a review that will determine whether they express "improper ideology."
item.content:encoded:
The White House says the Smithsonian Institution must submit materials about current and upcoming exhibitions and events for a review that will determine whether they express "improper ideology."

(Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: A conservative Supreme Court tackles the question of trans women in school sports
item.description: The first case involves an Idaho student barred by state law from trying out for the track team; the second was brought by a West Virginia middle schooler barred by state law from competing.
item.content:encoded:
The first case involves an Idaho student barred by state law from trying out for the track team; the second was brought by a West Virginia middle schooler barred by state law from competing.

(Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Trump continues to threaten military action against Iran amid deadly protest crackdown, Minnesota officials file lawsuit over ICE tactics, SCOTUS to hear cases on trans women in public school sports.
item.content:encoded: Trump continues to threaten military action against Iran amid deadly protest crackdown, Minnesota officials file lawsuit over ICE tactics, SCOTUS to hear cases on trans women in public school sports.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: 250 years of U.S. history was projected on the Washington Monument. A lot was missing
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep explores the Trump administration's portrayal of 250 years of U.S history captured on the Washington Monument.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep explores the Trump administration's portrayal of 250 years of U.S history captured on the Washington Monument.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Thousands of New York City nurses strike for second day
item.description: Fifteen thousand nurses are striking in New York City for a second day, seeking better pay and protection from workplace violence, among other concessions.
item.content:encoded: Fifteen thousand nurses are striking in New York City for a second day, seeking better pay and protection from workplace violence, among other concessions.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Lewis

item.title: Markets and restaurants return to Gaza, but few can afford the expensive price tag
item.description: New eateries are popping up in Gaza after months of famine, but it's pricey and many people still rely on aid to survive.
item.content:encoded: New eateries are popping up in Gaza after months of famine, but it's pricey and many people still rely on aid to survive.
item.dc:creator: Aya Batrawy

item.title: Buddhist monks on walk for peace journey from Texas to Washington, D.C.
item.description: A group of Buddhist monks is walking from Texas to Washington, D.C., spreading a message of peace and gaining supporters as they stop in local communities along the way.
item.content:encoded: A group of Buddhist monks is walking from Texas to Washington, D.C., spreading a message of peace and gaining supporters as they stop in local communities along the way.
item.dc:creator: Scott Morgan
